posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
So I had a bit too much free time this weekend, and accidentally wrote a super basic machine learning pipeline for Photon using the new OpenCV DNN module. That picture’s running a pre-trained YOLOv4 model at 640x640 on my poor CPU. It was shockingly easy to get this MVP spun up and plumbed into our UI and targeting data.

image 1214×1370 205 KB

image 1214×1370 205 KB

image 1214×1370 205 KB

However, this is also sort of the limits of my knowledge, as Machine Learning things go. I’m more than happy to support any changes to Photon’s internals, but would be interested in finding some contributors with more time and also domain knowledge to push this through. I know that Orange Pi/RK3588s have a NPU, but our efforts so far to use that with a custom trained model haven’t been successful yet. And OpenCV DNN seems to support CUDA for Jetson-based boards, not that anyone seems to be using Jetsons these days.

Anyways, ping me (Matt) on Discord or drop a comment on the PR, or fork Photon and take a stab at some things yourself!

link_counts.title: Add OpenCV DNN pipeline by mcm001 · Pull Request #928 · PhotonVision/photonvision · GitHub

posts.cooked:
thatmattguy:

I know that Orange Pi/RK3588s have a NPU, but our efforts so far to use that with a custom trained model haven’t been successful yet.

I did some initial work on this but ran out of time to continue hacking away at it with college starting. Happy to help walk someone through the steps to get this working.

Just to add on to Matt’s post on a more general note, I just wanted to highlight what a great opportunity this is for people to start getting involved in open source software. Through contributing to PhotonVision, you’re able to contribute to something that is used by teams all across the world and gain valuable experience. On top of the technical experience, you gain important, programming adjacent skills that directly translate to your classes in college or future job (if you go into software development), like how to actually use Git properly, developing in a collaborative software environment, bug hunting, navigating a large codebase, and a lot more. From a career standpoint, it also looks pretty good to employers as open source contributions, collaborative software development, and everything else you learn are valuable to them. I know this experience helped @bankst land one of their jobs working in a similar computer vision related space and is something I’ve had the chance to talk about again and again at career fairs, interview, networking events, etc. So overall, a good time where you learn a lot and can help yourself and others!

If you’re not into ML but still want to help out, feel free to join our discord and let us know what you’re interested in!

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Thanks! This is pretty awesome. I think dealing with hardware accel things will probably be the biggest pain point, if most people use Pi’s. Hopefully someone will make progress on using the Orange Pi/rk3588 NPU v2. I’m pretty sure we could just build opencv with cuda enabled for jetson and opencv DNN would Just Work, although maybe there’s some gotchas in missing

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: I’d love to help! I’ve been playing with YOLO for about a year now and I took UofM’s Deep Learning course over the summer. (this also sounds like a good excuse to buy a orange pi) I also some google corals.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: One big problem I’m seeing is using Java has a huge limitation with ML. Some sort of Python backend would have to be made to make this efficient and have the ability to use a modern version of YOLO. This would also allow cross platform support.

Ideally, we would just have all the ML code in C++/C and we can just write a JNI for it.

This is the pipeline I had in my head:

A model is trained for next years game and a .onnx format is output.

That model is converted to RKNN (the format that can be used on the Orange Pi 5 / similar SBC)

Code is written to perform inference using this new RKNN model in C/C++

A JNI is written to allow us to call the inference code, ideally passing in an input image and getting the bounding boxes / labels out as a result. This will internally handle any of the model loading / whatever, the user won’t be able to upload it themselves.

If the user’s device is a Orange Pi 5 / something with an RK3588, there will be an option for an ML pipeline.

This makes it easier for the users as they can avoid many of the pitfalls that you run into when converting to RKNN models. This does limit users to those who have an Orange Pi 5, but an additional iteration on top of this could add support for things like coral. Supporting other platforms would be great but you have to start simple first, especially with how good of a deal the OPi5 is.

I can help out with steps 1 to 2. I got up until step 3, but started running into issues with getting the code working with soemthing that isn’t their example model. Feel free to join our discord and I can walk you through how far I’ve gotten there.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Also, the POC code I wrote is using OpenCV DNN. Which so far has been happy to load any old model, as long as my opencv supports decoding it (like I would need protobuf for onnx iirc?). Python libraries offload all of their math anyways; any python code is a hard no for me
Random question, but would theoretically be possible to use the orange pi NPU with a google coral to increase performance even more?

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: They use different models so you can’t split them across each other, plus the NPU is ~1.5x faster than a coral (i might be wrong)

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: I found this repo (it’s in Chinese so you’ll have to translate it), they got YOLOv5S running at ~140fps on the RK3588. They’re using C++ so we should just be able to use that as a base. Ultralytics also has some C++ code but it’s only for ONNX.

link_counts.title: GitHub - leafqycc/rknn-cpp-Multithreading: A simple demo of yolov5s running on rk3588/3588s using c++ (about 142 frames). / 一个使用c++在rk3588/3588s上运行的yolov5s简单demo(142帧/s)。

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Yeah, second link won’t use the NPU I don’t believe. Good news is their code is in English at least!

Yes, this is the example code I referenced for my test. Their multi threading was glitchy and caused erreneous frames (with hundreds of detections) to come every so often. Single threaded implementations worked fine. I couldn’t get the C++ code working with a custom model.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
I integrated the output of the DNN pipe into the target tab. Performance on my CPU remains pretty abhorantly slow, which is to be expected lol. 640x640 is just too much for the poor thing. image 1607×775 276 KB
